  • Human minds are only one example of mind on earth. So what are those other minds really like?

    I think, therefore I am a human, a crow, a chimp, a bonobo — or a robot?

  • "The challenge was to reduce or remove the fear memory, without ever consciously evoking it"

    Overcoming phobias: how AI and scanning can be used to remove specific fears from the brain

  • “We’re interested in how people think”

    Invaluable advice to undergraduate applicants preparing for admissions interviews.

  • "Brexit has enormous implications across all spheres of life"

    Brexit Week: Listen to experts from Cambridge and beyond talk about how, why and what next for Brexit Britain

What's happening

Video and audio

Talking Politics: the Cambridge POLIS Podcast

David Runciman talks to Guardian journalist Gary Younge about the view of Trump and Clinton from Middle America, and what the election means for race, violence and poverty in the US. Plus, Fillon vs. Le Pen in France, and Renzi vs. everyone in Italy.

Read More
Research

Inspiring images invite you into the world of engineering

It could be a crystal ball from a mythical age showing the swirling mists of time, but James Macleod’s  image, which has won this year’s Department of Engineering Photography Competition, actually shows graphene being processed in alcohol to produce conductive ink.

Read More
Research

Dish Life: a Cambridge Shorts film

Science is demanding as well as exciting. Dish Life, the final of four Cambridge Shorts films, compares the task of raising stem cells in the lab to the challenge of looking after a gang of unruly kids. In conversation with real-life children, scientists show how tricky it is to work with these ‘super cells’.

Read More
Research

Rice farming in India much older than thought, used as 'summer crop' by Indus civilisation

Thought to have arrived from China in 2000 BC, latest research shows domesticated rice agriculture in India and Pakistan existed centuries earlier, and suggests systems of seasonal crop variation that would have provided a rich and diverse diet for the Bronze Age residents of the Indus valley.

Read More
Video and audio

Navigating the Future

This week the Naked Scientists look at the science of finding your way, hearing about self-navigating trousers, super-powered GPS and the spacecraft charting their way through the Universe. Plus, are we ready for driverless cars?

Listen now
Research

Before race mattered: what archives tell us about early encounters in the French colonies

As Europe expanded its overseas colonies, fixed ideas of racial differences took hold. Historian Dr Mélanie Lamotte, whose forebears include a slave, is researching a brief period when European notions of ethnicity were relatively fluid.  Early French settlers believed that non-white inhabitants of the colonies could be ‘civilised’ and ‘improved’.

Read More
